definitions: become smaller in size, amount, intensity, or degree through gradual reduction
cause something to become smaller in size, amount, intensity, or degree
examples: The temperature will decrease significantly overnight this week
Sales numbers have been decreasing steadily since last quarter
We need to decrease our spending by twenty percent
The medication should decrease the swelling within two hours

definitions: order something by official authority or formal proclamation with binding force
make a legal decision or judgment in a court of law
examples: The king decreed that all citizens must pay higher taxes
The government decreed a national day of mourning yesterday
The judge decreed that custody should be shared equally
The court decreed the property division between the parties

definitions: cease to treat something as illegal or as a criminal offense through legislative change
examples: Several states have voted to decriminalize marijuana for personal use
The government plans to decriminalize certain minor drug offenses next year

definitions: convert encrypted data back into its original readable form using a key or password
examples: The software can decrypt files that were encoded last month
Security experts worked all night to decrypt the stolen messages

definitions: devote time, effort, or oneself completely to a particular task, purpose, or person
formally open or unveil a building, monument, or institution for a specific purpose
cite or nominate a book, performance, or achievement as being in someone's honor
examples: She dedicated her entire life to helping homeless children
He dedicates three hours every morning to practicing piano
They will dedicate the new library building next Tuesday afternoon
The mayor dedicated the memorial park to fallen soldiers
The author dedicated the novel to her late grandmother
The band dedicated their final song to the audience

definitions: arrive at a fact or conclusion by reasoning from known facts or evidence
examples: From the evidence, detectives deduced that two people were involved
Scientists deduced the planet's existence from gravitational data collected earlier

definitions: subtract an amount from a total, especially for tax or accounting purposes
take away a specified amount as an allowable expense or reduction
examples: The company will deduct taxes directly from your monthly paycheck
You can deduct charitable donations from your taxable income amount
The referee deducted two points for the illegal move yesterday
They deducted fifty dollars for the damage to the rental

definitions: regard or consider in a specified way, especially in formal or official contexts
examples: The committee deemed her qualified for the senior position
The court deemed the evidence inadmissible in this particular case

definitions: make something deeper by excavating, digging, or extending downward in physical space
become or make more intense, serious, or extreme in quality or feeling
develop greater knowledge, understanding, or insight into a subject or relationship
examples: Workers will deepen the harbor channel by ten feet
We need to deepen this hole for the fence post
The crisis continues to deepen as unemployment rises nationwide
Her voice deepened with emotion as she spoke
The course will deepen your understanding of molecular biology principles
Travel abroad helped deepen their appreciation of different cultures

definitions: fail to fulfill an obligation, especially to repay a loan or appear in court
automatically select or revert to a preselected option when no alternative is specified
examples: The company may default on its loan payments next month
If you default on your mortgage, the bank can foreclose
The program will default to English if no language is selected
The settings default to factory specifications after a reset

definitions: win a victory over someone in a battle, game, or other competition
prevent someone from being successful in achieving a plan or accomplishing something
reject or block a proposal, motion, or bill through voting or formal process
examples: Our team defeated the champions in yesterday's final match
Napoleon was finally defeated at the Battle of Waterloo
The security system defeated all attempts to break in
Bad weather defeated our plans for a picnic yesterday
Congress defeated the proposed tax increase by twenty votes
The board defeated the motion to change company policy

definitions: discharge feces from the body through the anus as a natural bodily function
examples: Most healthy adults defecate once or twice per day
The patient was unable to defecate for several days postoperatively

definitions: abandon one's country, cause, or organization to join an opposing one, typically in a treasonous way
examples: The spy defected to the enemy during the cold war
Several high-ranking officials defected from the regime last year

definitions: protect someone or something from harm, danger, or attack by fighting or resisting
speak or argue in support of someone or something that is being criticized or accused
compete to retain a title, position, or achievement in sports or competition
examples: The soldiers defended the fortress against enemy attacks all night
A mother bear will fiercely defend her cubs from danger
The lawyer will defend her client against all criminal charges
He defended his decision to close the factory last month
The champion will defend her title next month in Paris
The team is defending their unbeaten record this season successfully

definitions: put off an action, event, or decision to a later time than originally planned
submit to or acknowledge the merit of another person's judgment, opinion, or wishes
examples: The committee decided to defer the vote until next month
Many students defer their loans until after graduation is complete
I defer to your expertise on this technical matter entirely
The court will defer to the agency's interpretation here

definitions: make something dirty, impure, or corrupted, especially something that should be kept clean
treat a sacred place or thing with violent disrespect or damage its sanctity
examples: Industrial waste continues to defile the river and surrounding areas
They accused him of defiling the family's good name publicly
Vandals defiled the ancient temple with offensive graffiti last night
The invaders defiled the sacred burial grounds without any remorse

definitions: state or describe exactly the nature, scope, or meaning of something clearly
mark out the boundary or limits of something with precision or clarity
make up or establish the distinctive character or features of someone or something
examples: The dictionary defines this word as meaning courageous or brave
The contract clearly defines each party's responsibilities and obligations completely
The river defines the border between the two neighboring countries
These mountains define the western edge of the vast desert
Her kindness and generosity define who she is as person
This decision will define his presidency for generations to come

definitions: cause something moving to change direction by hitting or bouncing it at an angle
turn aside or cause someone to deviate from a course of action or criticism
examples: The goalie deflected the ball with his outstretched hand brilliantly
The shield deflected the arrow away from the soldier completely
She skillfully deflected questions about her personal life during interviews
He tried to deflect blame onto his colleagues unfairly yesterday

definitions: clear an area of forests or trees, typically for agricultural or commercial development purposes
examples: Logging companies have deforested thousands of acres this year alone
They plan to deforest the hillside for new housing development

definitions: change or spoil the usual shape or appearance of something through damage or alteration
become twisted, bent, or changed from the normal or original shape gradually
examples: The intense heat deformed the plastic container beyond recognition completely
Years of pressure had deformed the metal support beams significantly
The disease can cause bones to deform over time progressively
The rubber seal will deform under extreme temperature conditions naturally

definitions: illegally obtain money or property from someone by deception or fraudulent means deliberately
examples: The accountant defrauded investors of millions through false statements
They were convicted of defrauding the government through tax evasion

definitions: provide money to pay all or part of costs or expenses incurred by someone
examples: The grant will defray the costs of medical research equipment
Donations helped defray expenses for the charity event last month

definitions: remove the fuse from an explosive device to prevent it from exploding dangerously
make a tense, dangerous, or hostile situation less tense or dangerous through intervention
examples: The bomb squad carefully defused the device found at the airport
Experts worked for hours to defuse the unexploded ordnance safely
The mediator helped defuse tensions between the two rival groups
Her calm response defused what could have been a violent confrontation

definitions: openly resist or refuse to obey someone in authority or a rule boldly
appear to be impossible to do, explain, or believe according to normal expectations
examples: The rebels continue to defy government orders to surrender immediately
She defied her parents by dropping out of medical school
The magician's tricks seemed to defy the laws of physics
This ancient structure defies explanation by modern archaeological methods completely

definitions: decline or deteriorate physically, mentally, or morally into a worse state progressively
lose moral standards and become corrupt, immoral, or less respectable over time
examples: The discussion quickly degenerated into a shouting match between participants
Without maintenance, the building will degenerate into complete disrepair eventually
He feared society would degenerate without strong moral leadership guiding it
The party degenerated into chaos after midnight when fights began

definitions: reduce the quality, value, or strength of something through wear, damage, or neglect
treat someone with disrespect or contempt causing them to lose dignity or self-respect
break down or deteriorate chemically or biologically into simpler substances over time
examples: Pollution continues to degrade the air quality in major cities
Overuse will degrade the performance of the battery over time
The supervisor's constant criticism degraded employees in front of customers
Such treatment degrades human dignity and violates basic rights completely
Plastic takes centuries to degrade in landfills naturally without intervention
These chemicals degrade into harmless compounds within several days completely

definitions: postpone or defer an event, decision, or action until a later time intentionally
cause someone or something to be late or slow in arriving or progressing
hesitate or be slow in acting, deciding, or starting something important
examples: They decided to delay the meeting until everyone could attend
The launch was delayed due to unfavorable weather conditions yesterday
Heavy traffic delayed our arrival by almost two hours today
Technical problems delayed the flight departure for three hours yesterday
Don't delay in seeking medical help for serious symptoms immediately
She delayed making a decision until the last possible moment

definitions: entrust a task, responsibility, or authority to another person, typically a subordinate
send or authorize someone to represent others, typically at a conference or meeting
examples: The manager delegates routine tasks to junior staff members effectively
You need to delegate more responsibilities to your team members
Each state will delegate representatives to the national convention tomorrow
The union delegated three members to negotiate with management directly

definitions: remove written or printed matter by drawing a line through it or erasing completely
remove data or files from a computer or electronic device storage permanently
examples: Please delete the incorrect paragraph from the final document version
The editor deleted several unnecessary sentences from the manuscript yesterday
I accidentally deleted all my photos from the phone yesterday
Make sure to delete sensitive files before selling your computer

definitions: engage in long and careful consideration or discussion about something before deciding
examples: The jury will deliberate for several hours before reaching verdict
Congress deliberated the proposal for weeks before voting on it

definitions: cause someone to feel great pleasure, joy, or satisfaction through actions or qualities
take great pleasure or satisfaction in something or in doing something enjoyable
examples: The magician's performance delighted children at the birthday party yesterday
Her thoughtful gift delighted him more than words could express
She delights in telling stories about her travel adventures abroad
The chef delights in creating new recipes every single week

definitions: determine or fix the limits or boundaries of something precisely or officially
examples: The treaty clearly delimits the maritime boundaries between neighboring countries
We need to delimit the scope of this research project first

definitions: describe or portray something precisely and accurately in words or gestures carefully
indicate the exact position or outline of something by drawing or marking boundaries
examples: The report clearly delineates the responsibilities of each department member
The speaker delineated the main differences between the two theories
The architect delineated the floor plan with precise measurements yesterday
Bold lines delineate the borders between different ecological zones here

definitions: bring and hand over goods, letters, or parcels to the intended recipient
assist in the birth of a baby or give birth to a child
formally present or announce a speech, verdict, or official statement publicly
produce or achieve what is promised, expected, or desired by others
examples: The courier will deliver the package before noon tomorrow certainly
They deliver fresh groceries directly to your door every week
The doctor delivered three babies during her shift last night
She delivered twins at the local hospital yesterday morning safely
The president will deliver the keynote address at the conference
The judge delivered a guilty verdict after two hours deliberation
The new manager really delivered on her promise to improve
This product delivers excellent results every single time without fail

definitions: flood an area with a large amount of water suddenly and overwhelmingly
inundate or overwhelm someone with things or people to be dealt with
examples: Heavy rains deluged the coastal towns for three consecutive days
The broken dam deluged the valley within just thirty minutes
Reporters deluged the celebrity with questions about the scandal yesterday
The company was deluged with complaints after the service outage

definitions: research or investigate something thoroughly and in detail to uncover information
reach or dig into something, especially to search for or retrieve something
examples: Historians delve into archives to uncover forgotten stories from past
The journalist delved deep into corruption allegations for months continuously
She delved into her bag searching for the missing keys
Archaeologists delved carefully into the ancient burial site yesterday morning

definitions: ask for something forcefully, insistently, or urgently as if by right
require something as necessary, essential, or urgent for a particular purpose
examples: Workers demanded better wages and improved working conditions from management
The protesters demanded immediate action from the government officials yesterday
This job demands patience and excellent attention to detail constantly
The situation demands immediate action to prevent further damage occurring

definitions: set or mark the boundaries or limits of something clearly and precisely
examples: The fence demarcates the property line between the two estates
Yellow tape demarcated the crime scene from the public area

definitions: die or pass away, especially used in formal or legal contexts respectfully
transfer property or a title by will or lease upon death legally
examples: The monarch demised peacefully in her sleep last Tuesday night
He demised shortly after his hundredth birthday celebration last month
The estate was demised to his eldest son upon death
She demised the property to the charitable foundation in will

definitions: demonstrate how a product or piece of equipment works to potential customers
demolish or tear down a building or structure, informal usage
examples: The salesperson will demo the new software features this afternoon
They demoed the latest smartphone model at the technology conference
The crew will demo the old warehouse building next Monday
They demoed three houses to make room for parking space

definitions: pull or knock down a building or structure completely and deliberately
defeat someone utterly and completely in a competition or conflict decisively
comprehensively refute or destroy an argument, theory, or belief through reasoning
examples: Workers will demolish the abandoned factory building tomorrow morning early
The hurricane demolished dozens of homes along the coastal area
Our team demolished the opposition with a score of ten-nil
The champion demolished all challengers in under three rounds each
The professor demolished the student's argument with clear logical evidence
New evidence completely demolished the prosecution's case against the defendant

definitions: clearly show the existence or truth of something by giving proof or evidence
take part in a public protest or march to support or oppose something
show and explain how something works or how to do something practically
examples: The experiment demonstrates the effects of gravity on objects
Sales figures demonstrate strong growth in the third quarter period
Thousands demonstrated against the proposed legislation yesterday afternoon downtown
Workers demonstrated outside the factory for better working conditions daily
The instructor demonstrated the proper technique for using the equipment
Let me demonstrate how this new feature works for everyone

definitions: be a sign or indication of something specific or serve as a name
have something as a typical feature or main characteristic that distinguishes
examples: The red light denotes danger in most warning systems worldwide
This symbol denotes the location of emergency exits in buildings
Dark clouds usually denote the approach of a storm system
Her frown denoted displeasure with the committee's decision yesterday clearly

definitions: publicly declare someone or something to be wrong, evil, or deserving condemnation
inform against someone to the authorities, especially for political or moral reasons
examples: The senator denounced the policy as discriminatory and unconstitutional yesterday
Religious leaders denounced violence against innocent civilians in speeches today
Neighbors denounced him to the secret police during the war
She was denounced as a traitor by former colleagues publicly

definitions: make a hollow or depression in a surface by impact or pressure
have an adverse effect on or reduce something slightly but noticeably
examples: The hailstorm dented the car roof in several places yesterday
He accidentally dented the refrigerator door while moving furniture around
The scandal barely dented his popularity among loyal supporters nationwide
High prices haven't dented consumer demand for luxury goods yet

definitions: refuse to give or grant something requested or desired to someone
state that something declared or believed to be true is actually untrue
refuse to acknowledge or accept the existence or truth of something
examples: The bank denied his loan application due to poor credit
They denied her access to classified documents without proper clearance
The suspect denied all charges against him in court yesterday
She denied spreading rumors about her colleagues at work recently
He continues to deny the scientific evidence of climate change
Some people deny the severity of the current economic crisis completely

definitions: leave or go away from a place, especially to start a journey
deviate or differ from an established course, pattern, or principle
examples: The train departs from platform three at exactly noon today
All guests must depart the hotel by eleven o'clock checkout
The director departed from the original script in several scenes
This ruling departs from established legal precedent significantly and controversially

definitions: rely on someone or something for support, help, or survival needs
be controlled, determined, or decided by a particular factor or circumstance
examples: Children depend on their parents for food and shelter daily
Many families depend on government assistance to meet basic needs
Success depends on careful planning and consistent hard work together
The outcome will depend on weather conditions tomorrow morning entirely

definitions: show or represent something by drawing, painting, or other artistic forms
describe or portray something in words giving a particular impression or image
examples: The painting depicts a peaceful rural scene from nineteenth-century England
The mural depicts important moments in the city's historical development
The novel depicts life in Victorian London with remarkable detail throughout
The documentary depicts the harsh realities of wartime experiences vividly

definitions: use up the supply or resources of something substantially or completely
reduce the number, quantity, or strength of something severely through consumption
examples: Mining operations have depleted the region's natural resources over decades
Overfishing continues to deplete fish stocks in many ocean areas
The long illness depleted his energy and financial savings completely
Years of drought have depleted the underground water reserves significantly
